pros: - Family-oriented - Employee welfare is good
cons: There are no cons that I could think of!

pros: The Cons negate all the Pros
cons: Worst re-organization ever. All the promotion glaringly shown that merit are not appreciated in the company, but rather who is your 'friend' and who is your 'enemy'. All the yes man are promoted, and those that challenge the status quo are being left out. Those that are capable and shown great result before this are all demoted or let go. Those you can see at the LT or Middle Management are all bootlickers, all fluff, and without knowledge how to drive the company forward. No one has any actual idea how to navigate and bring the organization to next level. Always the BS talks and never ending shitshow works well in the new structure.

pros: products have been in the markets for a long time
cons: working here is career suicide. dont be fooled by the branding and insincere pitches at the beginning. things were good in the past, but the golden days have already seen sunset. the new leadership is very weak and there are leaders without good educational degrees or the right experiences for the roles. nothing is easier for people who never do anything themselves than to criticise others who actually make an effort. the whole environment is like that where company departments fight with one another and management remain uncaring as long as they meet their profit margins. a lot of games are being played behind the scenes, and management greed is at an all time high. people are fired for no good reason and some have even been threatened. i know people who have been asked to dig dirt on employees who may want to leave. very unethical practices throughout. i do not advise anyone to work here.

review_title: Shameful HR practices - a shame for a global brand
pros: Foreigners are cheap so may foreigners are hired in place of locals (if that can be considered a pro at all)
cons: High turnover in the company so much so that we dont recognise half the people in the office anymore. People come and go so quickly that one minute they are here and the next they have disappeared. HR has been asked to "clean up" the mess that managers have created and deal with their bad decision making. Company holds meetings to try to find dirt on employees and try to make them leave. Complete lack of professional HR practices and non existent workforce planning an this is a huge shame for a company that considers itself "inclusive". So many good people have come to the company only to leave with a bad taste in their mouths and without ever finding their footing due to lack of role clarity and proper onboarding.

review_title: Alleviate pain, restore health, and extend life.
pros: Medtronic is a company which put its patient first. The mission of "alleviate pain, restore health, and extend life" has been there for more than 50 years. The quality culture is built in the blood of every employees.
cons: Recent organizational changes has been unsettling. And with the nature of medical devices industry, driving changes is difficult yet the goal can be challenging.

review_title: Beware of huge career risk at this company
pros: Just a big brand company
cons: unethical HR practices and volatile decision making which changes almost every month or in some cases, every week. Managers are weak and cannot protect their own staff. I have no idea what most managers are doing or getting paid for as so many corporate staff do not even have basic experience for the job roles they are doing. Some are transferred into the roles although they do not even want it because they have no choice. Any change in decision based on whims and fancies can make or break one's career within a day. Things used to be so much more stable here but now so many offices are in complete chaos. At one point, mass hiring can be witnessed but that was bad decision making and now its mass firing once they know the report targets cannot be met or achieved. This company is unethical so you need to be like them in order to make career moves. They are losing most of their shareholders and partners if not only for their big brand name. I would also be wary of the positive reviews on glassdoor as it seems like HR has asked people to write those.

review_title: Great place to work but too much change

cons: Too much change over last 3 years, first global restructuring into new operating units, then a new geographical restructuring, then a further APAC revamp of restructuring after APAC president left-- too much change--to many role changes--too much uncertainty

review_title: Company in sharp decline after APAC president left
pros: "great place to work" is a joke
cons: Village mentality. People of same village will hire ppl from same village regardless of competence level. So many redundant directors and useless roles that can be easily consolidated. All the talented people have left and those staying around are mostly incompetent and paying the price for the incompetencies of leaders. They talk a big talk about diversity and being a good place, but it's all downhill now. There is no proper structure in APAC. So many business functions are in a complete mess with no one looking out for them. HR is hiring and firing as and when they please with zero processes or business thinking behind their decisions. The kind of HR practices that go on here will be considered unacceptable in other proper organisations, other reviews have mentioned corruption and this is highly possible. Lousy directors are winning awards which is an inside joke among employees. These leaders have minds that run on loud machinery and big words with zero ability to grasp actual ideas.

pros: If you don't do work, your boss won't load you with more things
cons: If you can do work, your boss will give you more

pros: Free food, but even that is getting worse.
cons: I havent seen a HR that is more clueless about what they are doing than the HR at Medtronic and dont expect them to treat you like a human being after your successful interview. They also pay for all the awards and pretend it's their good work. Management has zero insight about what is happening at an APAC level and making "strategic changes" but all by "generals" who are saddled by their own incompetence and insecurities, accustomed only to being political and backside kissing.

review_title: Division and Exclusion are key values that no one talks about
pros: Given the mass firing, if you still have job here, you're considered a jackpot winner - or a cheap foreigner.
cons: Many reviews have stated all the cons, and even though everyone knows we are in a downturn, the least HR can do is manage the layoffs with better integrity and ethics. Employees are completely disengaged and unhappy with the new changes because none of these changes work in the favour of employees but more to serve the ego of management. Travel budgets are mismanaged and spent on the wrong people, and yet they keep saying they need to cut costs. No one is properly qualified or acting in the true interest of the company to analyse spending. No real work is being done by people at the top, and many are just very good at pretending to be busy and then going away on leave. Why are the working class not better protected against these lazy bosses? All the regions, countries, are in a huge mess and yet we need to put on an expensive quarterly spectacle of how much "good" we have done with honestly very little to show for it. My manager does not even have the proper management or communications skills but has been promoted to director because she is loud and noisy. As they say, an empty vessel makes the most noise....

review_title: Had a wonderful 8 years, though the recent integration with Covidien has been challenging. Great and reliable products.
pros:
Legacy Medtronic still has a warm and closely knit culture within the existing departments.

Medtronic generally has been known in medical and academic circles as having some of the best and most rigorously journaled products, and generally is the brand of choice of implants for VIPs.
cons:
Salary increments are painfully minimal (regardless of performance) - make sure you negotiate as high a pay as possible upon entry. You'll unlikely get a decent pay jump unless you move on else where, even doing so just to result in a counter-offer.

Integrating with Covidien also means Medtronic has been inheriting outdated policies - like hard copy approvals instead of email/digital approvals, for many simple things. The past few years has seen considerable increase of red tape and paperwork, without hiring the additional manpower to handle them.

Integration (between Medtronic and Covidien) has been problematic for the past few years. General consensus suggests that the internal cultures have soured with the onslaught of new faces, while proper cohesion efforts have been nonexistent.

Some managers just say whatever that will make themselves look powerful/resourceful/useful, at the expense of humiliating you. You will not come into their minds until the blaming game starts. All the advocates on looking at the real root cause are just talks. It is all about politic games. Shame on this because you are supposed to make a medical device that saves human life, not using them for your selfish move. Also, you got to grow your capability as a manager if you want to have such a big ego.

For some unknown reason, most colleagues are not helpful to the newcomers. You got to learn most of the thing the hard way. 

In summary, don’t join this company until you know the coy culture has improved. The culture was too unbearable for me. Also, eat healthier. Because, after working there, I know I don’t want to have a pacemaker installed inside me

review_title: Shareholder friendly but employee unfriendly company
pros:
- if it aligns with your values, mission can be inspiring
- Great company to retire - things move slow, but generally safe place to work
cons:
- Medtronic is brutal at enforcing their culture
- Generally most benefits are designed for VP levels and above
- Extremely frugal especially towards lower and middle level management employees
- Too many levels and hierarchies and too big for employees to be noticed
- Newer offices have workspaces that are open and extremely basic.  Offices do not have enough meeting rooms or areas for private conversations.
- Whether you are Executive assistant or Director - all get same basic work space and general benefits

pros: Good work-life balance. Comfortable for those who do not have an ambitious career. Some office locations have nice facilities - often a perk to have free parking if company have its own facility building.
cons: Regional and local management (top and middle) are very poor and weak. Leaders do not walk the talk. Structure is a mess and causes bad or no collaboration among all functions. Not a good place for functional employees as they are often not recognized for their efforts. Some of its processes and policies are very backwards which definitely needs alot of improvements. Company is weak with talent management which is almost equals to none or selective. Company often consider external resources than internal ones. Training programs are not effective.

review_title: Good learning ground but be prepared to have minimal work life balance for Sales and Marketing
pros: Good pay with great employee benefits and regional exposure. Unlike many other companies, Medtronic has good HR leadership who strategies and introduces good policies for employees to create a good working environment. There is continuous training and gives opportunities to employees, depending on which business unit you worked for.
cons: Too much politics, team spirit is not strong in most business units as many employees focus on personal benefits and advancement without taking the company overall result as part of the consideration. Upper management in ASEAN office does not have good mid-term and long-term strategies to bring the company forward. Too many expats in the company who do not contribute the level of work equivalent to their payroll.

Medtronic is general is an excellent company. But Medtronic Singapore Operations is a pathetic place to work.

2) You get to work with some amazing products that has a great impact on human life.

1) Management is totally Lost. They just need to over write one another's decisions. None of them takes responsibility for what they asked the people to do. review_title: 15 months, three different managers, disparity between company goals and actions
job_title: Principal Financial Systems Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The comp is pretty good and the people are friendly.
cons: At the time, the company was claiming as a goal to be "the leading medical technology company" while also not requiring vaccines for COVID-19 to return to the office. Management moved to have everyone return to the office for a few days a week, but with no requirements for vaccination, or any other non-medical interventions. I asked if I would be able to stay fully remote given that everyone I work with is out of state and was told no, without any reason given. I also was hired by one manager who knew that I would be moved to another team within three months, did not tell me this during the interview process, and was then moved to another manager eight months later.

review_title: Talented Individuals as input but poor products as output
pros: 1. You are working at the biggest medical device company in the world. 2. Mature process for product development 3. Talented coworkers that can teach you a bonch
cons: Talented individual contributors are not enough for a successful company and products. If you search online, you can see all the competitors'' product releases and FDA approvals over the years with so many advanced sometime mind-blowing technologies. However, at Medtronic Diabetes the technology is so old and conservative, which makes the diabetes BU's financial performance poorly over the years. Higher level leaders might care more about their job securities, so think less on innovations but how to integrate more power and resource; at least that was what happened in my team. At the end of the day, doctors and patients are the ones to make decision on what products they will buy. It is sad to see how a start-up company got acquired by Medtronic and now it is so behind the cutting-edge technology.

review_title: love this team, don't love the hours
job_title: Senior Clinical Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The company is supportive of my personal needs outside the job. There are no "bad eggs" on my team, and I owe that to the selective hiring process of my managers. I feel like I can communicate any issues to my manager and be met with understanding and action.
cons: If the job was 40 hours a week with guaranteed time for lunch I'd never leave! But I understand what I signed up for- the medical field will never be structured like an office job.

review_title: Great company but out of touch leaders
job_title: Senior Diabetes Therapy Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great company benefits, insurance, maternity leave, PTO Rewarding work - you genuinely get to make a difference in people’s lives
cons: Very hard to get promoted - the goal post is constantly being moved and it mostly comes down to luck if you get a good territory and TM. Limited number of people allowed to work remote and no hybrid work model. Current leadership would rather lose top talent instead of allowing employees to continue working from home. More work continues to be added to this position with no increase in pay

review_title: Great company to work for, but prepare for zero career progression
pros: Had an amazing team, great benefits, work from home, and solid work life balance.
cons: The company does not value long time employees at all. I was at the company for 2.5yrs and in that time never received a significant raise or promotion. The best they could do was an annual raise of 2% which is terrible considering the rate of inflation is 7.7%. What also made me mad is people fresh out of college were getting hired and paid for the same position I had been in for 2.5yrs. It got to the point where I had to value my own dignity over the job. The only metric upper management cares about is stock price. In my 2yrs there we never once received a full bonus due to "underperforming". Which never made sense to me because my operating unit always over preformed or met all quarterly goals. So it felt like we were being punished for other teams underperforming, but hey at least CEO Geoffrey Martha was able to be compensated $16.8 million this year.

pros: Neuro is great, customers still want reps in their cases, Medtronic overall has big pull in most hospitals.
cons: Neuro division is struggling to keep up with innovation and losing marketshare, haven't hit a number in many quarters. Blockbuster products are now 10-15 years old now and more competitors to bite marketshare. Neuro Leadership offered secretive guarantees to a small handful of selected reps and those who didn't get one of the secretive guarantees left wondering what the criteria was. Bad for morale and trust. D&I breakdown is poor.

review_title: Sense of mission, but questionable DEI strategies
job_title: Sr. Principal Engineer in North Haven, CT
pros: Medtronic has a strong focus on the patient, good pay, and flexible work arrangements in many cases.
cons: The corporate strategy for DEI is equity (not just equal opportunity), so there is a strong push to hire based on gender and race. Leadership is well-intentioned, but this approach is based on numerous flawed assumptions, and it is causing division and hard feelings among employees.

pros: Large company with good reputation. A good number of high end products and a solid pipeline of new therapies, devices and technology.
cons: The Clinical / research function is largely ignored by the local business management team. The Clinical group has been consolidated into a cross-business team covering all therapeutic areas, and the Director of that group is unfit for the role. Advancement is limited, new ideas aren’t welcomed, workload is unbalanced between the team members. Favouritism is rife and the culture overall is toxic. The larger business as a whole has changed since the new global CEO took over. There is now a “win at all costs” mentality, and the old mantra about putting patients first has been lost. This culture has filtered down through all levels of management and has given scope for tyrants to flourish.

pros: Benefits were great and my manager was nice.
cons: Medtronic does not give a cost of living adjustment. All clinical specialist in your same division will make the same amount, no matter where you live across country. No work life balance. In fact, they say there’s “work life integration”, basically meaning you are available all the time depending on what division you’re in, especially as a clinical specialist. You can work very hard and it might get noticed with recognize points, but good luck on a raise or promotion. They haven’t given a yearly raise in several years to their employees on salary. I was offered a well deserved promotion but the district manager said it wasn’t in the budget and I’d have to wait several months. However, the associate sales rep was promoted within that same time frame. They definitely care more about their sales team members than they do their clinical team. Other companies pay their clinical specialist a bit more than Medtronic.

pros: I am perfectly happy working at Medtronic. I was hired during the pandemic and so I started remote and have been fully remote for the last 10 months. Just this month they are having us move to a hybrid schedule where we're required to go into the office ~4 days/month. Really not bad, especially since I expected to go in when I was hired. Great work life balance, decent pay, and you know what's expected of you. I will say your teammates and supervisor can make or break your experience here. Overall, I would recommend it to others.

A lot of back orders and slow FDA review can make for frustrated customers, but that's not just with Medtronic.

Team members are required to send rewards to each other and no rewards received means low annual review. Managers like to employ people straight from uni or changing careers as only those will work hard for the peanuts that are being offered and can be easily micromanaged. Office management as well as other corporate teams treat employees like a nuisance and a piece of excrement. Everything you'd need as an employee is very hard to get, starting from day one when nothing is ready for you and it seems as if you're the first new starter ever. HR team is making employees' lives miserable and it is impossible to get anything done by them, while it is also impossible to escalate any issues with them. Local management promotes rude, passive-agressive and toxic behaviour and if you're not like that, you're out. Higher Medtronic management is detached from the lower tiers and live in a completely different dimension with no insights as to what happens to regular employees. Lastly and sadly, most of the positions in the Prague office are very poorly paid, benefits are only ordinary and there are virtually no career opportunities.

review_title: Company Culture Is Improving But Has A Long Way To Go
job_title: Sales Program Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
-Fairly competitive compensation packages, with really good benefits

-Lots of different business units, so there's opportunity to work in various sub-markets within med device industry

-Depending on your manager, there's generally decent work/ life balance
cons:
-Career development isn't a real thing at Medtronic. It happens on paper, annually via the goal-setting process, and usually isn't deliberately championed by managers (leaders use the cop-out phrase "you really own your career here")

-Professional development is usually supported in name only, too. This is different from career devt. in terms of it focusing on the more tactical activities/courses/trainings/etc. that might help you advance in your CAREER. Even if your manager SAYS they're willing to fund prof devt. opportunities for you, that funding will usually get cut in order manage expenses right before the end of the quarter. Yet... it happens Every. Single. Quarter.

-If you want to explore different jobs within Medtronic, if you apply to them, your boss is notified. You might not even get an INTERVIEW for the role, your boss will still know if you apply. And it's not uncommon for you to NOT get that interview because your boss interceded via HR bc "losing headcount right now would put XYZ initiatives at risk."

-At Medtronic, you won't move up in your career unless you make the right friends. You could be an absolute all-star and still not get promoted because you're not on the right people's radar. I know this is common in lots of companies, but Medtronic does it really well. I don't think HR has even heard the word "meritocracy," let alone know what it means.

review_title: Many brilliant people, but as an organization, creaking and failing.
pros: You will work with many very smart people-so for example, a client might be someone with a Ph.D in Neuroscience from an Ivy League, or similar. The mission of the company is great, and some teams have great culture.
cons: I think the high point and best days of this company were in the past. Part of the reason is the level of innovation and impact was much higher. The company was once an Engineer's company-you either had an engineering/science degree or had an affinity for that, or else you were definitely support. So-Finance used to be basically in a basement somewhere, and were there to support brilliant engineers and techs build great products. Now-finance and various process groups run the show. The average person spends more time and effort trying to comply with processes, figure out which charge code to use, maintain old systems to be compliant, etc. It is increasingly difficult to hire an actual engineer. Instead, the company continues to build out PMO groups, governance groups, Diversity and Inclusion Groups (I fully support the movement to Inclusion-but it is starting to build its own bureaucracy and increasingly dysfunctional. How many Diversity Directors can you actually employ, and is this actually helping historically disadvantaged groups). If I were a director, I would want to understand how every new hire is going to get products that help customers and make money to market faster. If you can hire that person-do it. If you are building a group that will slow that down? Don't hire for it. Morale is terrible here, attrition is bad and will get worse.

review_title: Good place to work if you want an average job
pros:
- Very nice people that work there.
- Decent benefits.
- Freedom to choose how to do work.
- Room for growth vertically and horizontally.
- Upper management cares about making beneficial changes.
cons:
- Company is extremely large so if you can feel insignificant. I'm on a great team though so that balances things out. It can be lonely if you're on an unsupportive team.
- Poor HR department (not the people just the way it's structured). It's difficult to get in contact with an actual person and even people in the HR department had trouble finding my representative.
- Funding is distributed poorly so some departments are overfunded while the departments that needed it are severely underfunded. That makes training/advancing your career difficult and salaries can be far below value depending on where you work.
- Upper management can be a bit oblivious to unhealthy behaviors and people get promoted simply because of the time they've been there, not because they possess the skills and emotional maturity to do the job. You have to be cautious when interviewing to make sure your manager is prepared for that position.

job_title: Technical User Support Analyst in Columbia Heights, Optional[MN]
pros: This is a company that makes live-saving products and is known worldwide as the creator and innovator of these parts. It's a good feeling to work at a wholesome place that makes products that keep lots of people alive, as opposed to some dim job at a soulless bank or insurance company. Stability? Well aside from the current wave of outsourcing it's stable - the world will always need this company's products and will pay money for them. Benefits? If you make it on as an FTE you've got almost the gold standard of health insurance and PTO.
cons: Nobody in this department, including managers, have much pull. That's they reason they are stuck here. They want out too. They act like they do, but they don't. Don't fall for the hype. There isn't much of a way up and out of this entry-level job. Maybe 1% of people actually move out of the IT Support Center onto something else. Like any job - if you don't move up in 2 yrs, move on. The IT Support Center is put in a separate dingy building that the rest of Medtronic forgot about; visit any other office at Medtronic and it's modern, airy and pleasant, but Sullivan Lake is stuck in 1979 and is just not a very comfortable place to be. Some of your peers are brilliant, many are not so brilliant, because this is the best job they could pull off out of college. You'll constantly be sold this hype of helping others and "saving lives". We don't save lives. We deal with people's jacked-up iPads and email, don't flatter yourself, you're not a doctor, it's the same exact role as at any other corporation on earth in an IT helpdesk. A lot of IT at this company feels out of date in ways, as if the company repeatedly slaps bandaids on perpetually broken systems rather than exerting time and effort to replace or upgrade them.
